Supreme Court Limits Scope Of Appeals By Death-Row Inmates

Jay Goodman Tamboli | Monday, April 4, 2011 at 12:24PM | Share Article | Email Article | Print Article

When a federal court hears an appeal from a death-row inmate, the federal court is not allowed to consider new evidence, according to a Supreme Court decision handed down today. The case was an appeal from Scott Lynn Pinholster, who was convicted of beating and stabbing two men to death in 1982. The Supreme Court went on to say that Pinholster’s death-penalty sentence should remain even if the new evidence were considered.

In an opinion written by Justice Clarence Thomas and joined by 6 other Justices, the Court analyzed the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, known as AEDPA. AEDPA requires prisoners to appeal to state courts before going to federal courts for help.

In this case, Pinholster twice appealed all the way up to the California Supreme Court, arguing that his court-appointed lawyers failed to present mitigating evidence about possible mental illness during the penalty phase of his trial. Only after Pinholster appealed to the federal court system did he introduce statements from a psychiatrist and school records suggesting “some degree of brain damage.”

In all, seven Justices agreed that the federal court should not have considered the new evidence but should instead have limited itself to considering whether the state courts made the appropriate decision based on the evidence the state courts had seen.

Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the only Justice who has served as a trial court judge, dissented, saying that it is already difficult enough for prisoners to present evidence in federal appeals under AEDPA and that there are good reasons for a federal court to hear new evidence.

The case is Cullen v. Pinholster
